name: Multi-Strain Probiotics
summary: Multi-strain probiotics combine different beneficial bacterial species to support gut health, immune balance, and potentially mood regulation. They may have synergistic effects on gastrointestinal and mental health outcomes compared to single-strain probiotics.
description: Multi-strain probiotics contain a combination of various beneficial bacteria, often including Lactobacillus, Bifidobacterium, and sometimes Streptococcus or Saccharomyces species. These supplements are designed to enhance microbial diversity, restore gut microbiome balance, and influence systemic health through the gut-brain axis. While single-strain probiotics have demonstrated targeted benefits, multi-strain formulations may provide broader or synergistic effects, including potential benefits for mood, anxiety, cognition, and immune function. They are widely available as dietary supplements and commonly used in integrative psychiatry.

metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for psychiatric or GI indications)

contraindications: Severe immunocompromise (e.g., chemotherapy, transplant, uncontrolled HIV)
Central venous catheters (risk of translocation and bacteremia in rare cases)
monitoring_required: Signs of infection in immunocompromised individuals

sections.text: Probiotics act by colonizing the gut, producing metabolites like short-chain fatty acids, modulating immune responses, competing with pathogenic microbes, and signaling through the gut-brain axis. Multi-strain formulations may enhance microbial diversity and provide synergistic effects.

adult.range: 10–200 billion CFU depending on formulation and indication

sections.pediatric: 5–20 billion CFU daily depending on product and age

sections.text: Onset: Days to weeks for digestive benefits. Duration: Continuous supplementation often required; microbiome effects diminish after discontinuation.

serious: Rare bacteremia or fungemia in immunocompromised patients

other: Safety in immunocompromised or critically ill patients is not well established.
Formulation-specific efficacy varies; not all strains are equally effective.

items: Mood and anxiety changes (if used for mental health)
Signs of systemic infection in high-risk populations

sections.pediatrics: Safe at lower CFU doses; evidence supports use in certain GI conditions
sections.geriatrics: Safe; may support immune and gut function

sections.text: No tapering required; discontinuation leads to gradual loss of colonization.

items: Evidence suggests multi-strain probiotics may be more effective than single-strain formulations for IBS and diarrhea prevention.
Some randomized controlled trials suggest mood and anxiety improvements, but effects are strain-specific.
Probiotic efficacy is highly dependent on strain selection, dosage, and individual microbiome composition.

items.label: Ford AC et al. Efficacy of probiotics in IBS. Am J Gastroenterol. 2014.
Wallace CJK, Milev R. The effects of probiotics on depressive symptoms. CNS Spectr. 2017.
